review_blob: Dark fizzy beer that does not hide its alcohol well. Dark fruits and malt and a hit of Christmas booze..
A delicious hoppy pilsner. Peach and mango notes. Moderate bitterness which could higher. Overall a bit dull..
Dark colour, lots of roast malt and spirit on the nose. Dark fruits, nuts and spice on the palate. Dry finish. Very Moorish.
Big apricots on the nose. Palate of oily hips, orange zest and apricots, sweet candied lemons and a bitter sweet finish of oranges

Dark gold and velvet smooth. Hints if orange peel and cloves.
Crisp and refreshing and full bodied. Very Moorish..

Its not overly hoppy which allows the malty background to shine and the maple to show through.
A touch of sweetness and hints of pecan and maple, serve ideally with a cheese board.

Amber gold colour with a frothy white gold head. Very BIG on the flavours of pine resin, grapefruit, candied orange. The finish is properly bitter and moreish. Its a classic IPA in style but very modern on the flavour profile.
Delicious pale ale with extra hops. Good solid percentage. Tropical fruits but not too in your face

Pale orange/ gold colour. Typical aromas of pineapple, grapefruit and orange from the Pacific Northwest hops. This is a subtle beer that doesnt slap you in the face with loads of flavour. Its more of a grower and the low ABV also helps make this a real winner. There are plenty of 6 or 7 % American pale ales that are very highly hopped out there already so it makes a nice change to not have the senses bombarded.
Flavours of pine and grapefruit and a hint of mango even. The finish is dry and more bitter than I was anticipating, which I think makes it a very moreish brew.
Dark gold. Citrus nose. Pine kernels and orange peel on the palate. Very dry Moorish finish. Mmmm
Dark chocolate in colour with a frothy white head. Sweet malty at first which leads to a dry, hoppy and bitter finish. Dark fruits and a touch of spice.

This is a super pale brew that leaps out of the bottle at you. Hazy pale straw with loads of white billowy head. Big hop aromas that are classically Nelson Sauvin: grapefruit, gooseberries and kumquat. The palate is lime peel and grapefruit, gooseberries and oranges.
Absolutely delicious and far too easy drinking for something knocking on 7%!

This is a very distinctive beer that will not be to everyones taste. The herbs and spices are very powerful and so this beer will be best tasted with equally distinctive food.
The sage and mint come through first and then the anise and sumac. I didnt get much camomile and the oregano (zaatar) is on the finish.
Delicious, but ultimately too weird to enjoy on its own as a refreshing beer, but with the right Middle Eastern dish this will really come into its own.
beer_name: 961 / Kissmeyer - Brewmasters Select 01 - Lebanese Pale Ale

review_blob:
Rye ales can become cerealy and too reminiscent of a bowl of Shreddies when overdone. One Claw is subtly rye influenced with lots of hops to balance. Clean and rich with lots of citrusy, grassy hops.
Grapefruit, mango and guava flood the palate. A superb rye pale at just the perfect ABV.
Classic English bitter with balances hops. Dark gold bordering on orange colour. Fruity, but not overly so, with a softly bitter finish. Very drinkable and blind I would have put at 4% not 5%!
beer_name: Brew By Numbers 02/12 Golden Ale - Liberty & Pacific Jade

review_blob: Delicious Pale Ale. Aroma of white flowers. Palate is almond and pine kernel. Nicely dry and bitter finish. Very Moorish!

The Amarillo comes out straight away with a pineapple / citrus note on the nose. Then on the palate the Simcoe shows through with its weighty fruit cocktail flavours, add to this the slight sour hint of the saison yeast and we end up with a very interesting chimera. Spicy, fruity, citrusy and weird.
beer_name: BrewDog / Stone / Magic Rock Magic Stone Dog

review_blob:
This is pale gold in colour, full bodied head with aromas of grapefruit and white flowers. 
Flavours of grapefruit and mango, citrus and pine abound. The malt background isnt overshadowed so there is a malty sub note. The finish is fully bitter, with a lasting citrus peel note. A very delicious and well balanced IPA.
A spot on the money Blonde style ale. Light fruity aroma with some yeasty esters. Light straw colour with a frothy head and lemongrass aroma. Notes of lemon, orange, grapefruit & peach.

As with the Brownstone this is a solid affair, a classic Pale Ale in the modern London style, IE quite American! But Adrain doesnt have any qualmes with that as his website announces "Beers from over there, brewed over here." Golden orange hue with a note of grapefruit, honey, citrus and white flowers. Eminently drinkable!
Thoroughly well built bitter. Deep amber colour, biscuit maltyness on the nose. Nutty and fruity with a slightly sweet malt background this is a delicious, morish ale.

Thick creamy head with refreshing Vienna malts imparting a light flavoursome malty foundation which the Tettnang, Bramling Cross and Cascade hops back up with a hint of fruity blackcurrant leaf, fresh straw, white flower and a hint of the fatty ester of almost but not quite un-smoked bacon. So weird and different from any other craft lager, it is also bottle conditioned! Light and delicate yet demanding your full attention this beer blew me away at the Summer Brew Fest, literally the most unexpectedly brilliant beer there, and there were plenty of REALLY great new beers to try.

Brewed with lots of Cascade hops this is a delicious Pale Ale with a bright golden colour and aromas of grapefruit and pineapple. The palate is pure oranges, oranges and more oranges!
Crisp and refreshing, moreish and orangey!
This is a super pale golden ale, loads of gooseberries and a touch of citrus. The "Sauvignon Blanc" charachteristic is strong with this one. Perfect sunny weather picnic beer even if it is 5.6%!
Delicate, thin, white head. Aroma of tropical fruit and baked bread. On the palatte mango and citrus which lead to a properly bitter finish. Delicious
